tweets.text:
1 like = 1 opinion on "Bridging subcultures that donâ€™t quite harmonize"

(It's not quite a natural category for me but it's what vgr gave me and I like a challenge! good way to draw out some implicit opinions. comment if you have more specific Qs) https://t.co/eAn0MhwZfX
1/ subcultures that don't quite harmonize are the norm, not the exception
2/ subcultures are fractal and fundamentally subjective. no two people live in quite the same subculture
3/ most co-mingling, in practice, happens by people managing to ignore differences, not by any real bridging

4/ real bridging would exploit the differences to create a parallax effect

https://t.co/RxIalNQvM1
5/ virtually all subcultures that exist include core assumptions that differences are wrongnesses, which is why ignoring differences tends to be the approach instead (#3)
6/ differing subcultures that can tap some deeper shared purpose will have an easier time bridging than those that cannot.

7/ that shared purpose can be a shared goal or a shared value, or both

https://t.co/JG0AkNPeI7
8/ in general, one needs both shared goal & shared value for an ongoing deep bridge
9/ note that because of the fractal thing, what I'm saying here applies to a collaboration between two individuals or honestly even a collaboration between multiple parts of *one* "in-dividual"

10/ honestly I'm kind of afraid of most subcultures and want nothing to do with them.

I think that's part of why I'm finding writing this thread hard

...is that true? idk. there's something true about it

11/ I guess on the scale of individual peoples' subcultures, as I've defined it, I can get pretty curious about somebody's assumptions/ontology etc

sort of like "there's more that can be said about one apple than about all apples"

12/ it seems to me (based on @cognazor & @JaredJanes talking on early BothAnd podcast about their appetite to be Memetic Mediators) that there are people who naturally gravitate towards wanting to do this bridging.

13/ one sort of bridging that I do feel more attracted to is like... via context-creation? eg Burning Man creates a new super-culture in which dissonant subcultures somehow come together coherently.

(caught up to likes, going to bed for now)
